message.content: This question involves knowledge of basic physics and the properties of water. Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius, so if you stick your hand in water above this temperature, it will scald your fingers. Option (A) is incorrect because freezing occurs at temperatures below 0 degrees Celsius. Option (C) is incorrect because water at high temperatures can actually worsen sores or wounds. Option (D) is incorrect because frostbite occurs at extremely low temperatures, not high temperatures.

This question requires knowledge about the temperature at which water boils. Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius. Therefore, if you stick your hand in water above 100 degrees Celsius, the water is at a temperature that can scald or burn your fingers. Option (A) is incorrect because water at that high of a temperature will not freeze anything. Option (C) is incorrect because water at high temperatures can actually worsen and further damage sores or wounds. Option (D) is incorrect because frostbite is caused by exposure to extreme cold, not high temperatures.
